Catalytic hydrochlorination of Si is an effective route to manufacture trichlorosilane (TCS), the main feedstock of high-purity Si for solar cells. However, the understanding of its catalytic process is still limited. Herein, we prepared CuO catalysts modified with Fe2O3 promoter (Fe2O3-CuO) by one-step hydrothermal method and investigated their catalytic performance for producing TCS. Compared with the non-catalytic case, pure CuO catalyst, and the Fe2O3-CuO-M catalyst obtained by mechanically mixing CuO with Fe2O3, the Fe2O3-CuO catalyst exhibits the highest TCS selectivity and Si conversion. The introduction of Fe2O3 facilitates lattice oxygen migration of CuO due to the electron interactions between Fe2O3 and CuO. During the reaction, CuO transforms into CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O, then to CuCl. The latter is the key intermediate for forming the active Cu x Si phase. This work discloses the transformation of the CuO catalyst during the Si hydrochlorination reaction, and provides new insights into the catalytic mechanism. Graphical Abstract In the catalytic Si hydrochlorination to trichlorosilane, CuO is firstly transformed into CuCl2 and CuCl2·2 H2O, then to CuCl and Cu, with the CuCl phase as the critical intermediate for forming the active CuxSi phase. Introducing Fe2O3 into CuO accelerates the phase transformation to CuxSi, thus enhancing catalytic performance. ga1 Keywords Si hydrochlorination Trichlorosilane Fe2O3-CuO Catalyst transformation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Trichlorosilane (SiHCl3, TCS) is the basic raw material for producing solar photovoltaic polysilicon [1–3] and a critical monomer and intermediate for synthesizing organosilicon products, such as organosilane, aryl, and organofunctional chlorosilane [4]. Therefore, there is a high demand for TCS in these application fields. Currently, TCS is mainly manufactured in the industry by Si hydrochlorination, which is the direct reaction of gaseous hydrogen chloride (HCl) with metallurgical-grade (MG) silicon (Si) without using any catalysts [5]. The corresponding reaction is expressed as follows: (1) 2Si (s) + 7HCl (g) → SiHCl3 (g) + SiCl4 (g) + 3 H2 (g) Since no catalysts are involved, this reaction process requires a high temperature above 300 °C and generates a large amount of silicon tetrachloride (SiCl4, STC) as a by-product. Therefore, various catalytic routes have been explored to improve TCS selectivity and yield at relatively lower temperatures. CuCl is often chosen as the catalyst in these “direct reaction,” e.g., the reaction of Si and methanol [6,7] and the reaction of Si and methyl chloride [8]. However, our previous works showed that Cu-based oxide catalysts with good stability and environmentally friendly advantages could enhance Si conversion and TCS selectivity in the hydrochlorination of Si, compared with the non-catalytic process [9–11]. In addition, the structure and electronic states of Cu-based catalysts directly affect the catalytic performance. For example, Yang et al. designed hexapod Cu2O@CuO with rough surfaces and an ordered structure and achieved improved activity. Li et al. reported that CuO-ZnO-In2O3 microspheres showed very high Si conversion and TCS selectivity, resulting from the tuned Cu electronic density by ZnO and In2O3. A similar promotion effect was also found in other CuO-based trimetallic oxides (CuO-M1O x -M2O y , where M1 and M2 = Zn, In, Fe, Ni, Mn, and Co). These reports also showed that the Cu-based catalysts used in the catalytic hydrochlorination of Si completely changed their structures after the reaction [9–12], different from the traditional heterogeneous catalysts. In detail, the initial CuO phase disappeared in the “waste contact masses” (the residual contains Cu catalyst and unconverted Si after the reaction), while new Cu and Cu x Si phases appeared [9–12]. Although these studies provide valuable information on Cu-based catalysts in the production of TCS from Si hydrochlorination, the phase transformation and intermediate phase of Cu-based catalysts during the reaction process have not been well studied. Moreover, among the various promoters, Fe with variable valences has shown promising promotion effects on Cu-based catalysts in Si hydrochlorination [10], but its promotion mechanism is still unclear. Therefore, it is worthwhile to further explore the application of the Fe2O3-CuO system for the hydrochlorination of Si due to its low cost and high catalytic activity. In this work, we synthesized the Fe2O3-CuO catalysts for Si hydrochlorination to TCS by a facile hydrothermal method. Activity tests showed that the Fe2O3-CuO catalysts exhibited higher TCS selectivity and Si conversion than the non-catalytic case, the cases with pure CuO catalyst and the Fe2O3-CuO-M catalyst obtained by mechanically mixing CuO with Fe2O3. It is found that the strong interaction between CuO and Fe2O3 could facilitate lattice oxygen migration, significantly accelerate the phase transformation of CuO, and leads to the formation of more active sites, thereby improving the catalytic performances. This work provides an alternate approach to producing TCS by the Cu-catalytic Si hydrochlorination. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials All the chemicals with analytical grade were used without further purification. Copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), iron nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), cuprous chloride (CuCl), and ethanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China. Si powder (>99.5 wt%) was provided by Xinte Energy Co., Ltd., China. High-purity anhydrous HCl (99.9%) gas was purchased by Beijing Huayutongfang Chemical Technology Development Co., Ltd., China. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The catalysts were prepared by a one-step hydrothermal method reported in our previous work [13]. Fig. 1 depicts these synthetic procedures. Typically, 20 mmol of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 0.4 mmol of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 120.0 mL of deionized water under vigorous stirring to form a homogeneous solution at room temperature. Then, 30.0 mL of Na2CO3 solution (0.4 M) was added, and the mixture was stirred continuously for another 15 min. Afterward, it was transferred into a stainless-steel autoclave with a 200 mL Teflon-lined container. The autoclave was sealed and kept at 140 °C for 10 h. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the resulting solid precipitate was recovered by filtration, then washed with deionized water (2000 mL) and ethanol (2000 mL) and dried at 60 °C overnight. Finally, the dried solid was calcined in a muffle furnace for 3 h at 450 °C. The obtained sample is named Fe2O3-CuO. Pure CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts were also prepared by hydrothermal method for comparison. In addition, pure CuO and Fe2O3 were mechanically mixed in the same Fe: Cu proportion as the Fe2O3-CuO catalyst and denoted as Fe2O3-CuO-M. 2.3 Characterization The crystalline phases of the catalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using the Kα radiation of Cu (λ = 1.5406 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA from 5.0° to 90.0° (PANalytica X′Pert PRO MPD). The morphology of the samples was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JEM-6700 F, JEOL, Japan) equipped with liquid-nitrogen-cooled energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). The detailed microstructures were observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM-2010, JEOL, Japan) operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The median diameter was measured by a laser-based particle size analyzer (BT-9300Z, Bettersize Instruments Ltd., China). Prior to the measurement, the catalyst was diluted with distilled water. Then the dispersion was added to a ultrasonic dispersion unit until a laser saturation of ca. 12–15 % was obtained. Three successive measurements were made for each sample to calculate the mean diameter. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured at − 196 °C using a Quantachrome NOVA 3200e instrument. Prior to the measurement, the catalysts were degassed at 200 °C for 2 h under a vacuum. The specific surface area was determined according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method in the relative pressure range of 0.05–0.3. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were performed on an automated chemisorption analyzer (Chem BET pulsar TPR/TPD, Quantachrome). First, 0.02 g of a sample was loaded into a quartz U-tube. Before the measurement, the sample was degassed at 100 °C under helium for 1 h. When the temperature was cooled to room temperature, the gas was switched to 10 vol% H2/Ar, and then the sample was heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under this atmosphere (30 mL·min−1). The surface chemical composition and valence state of the elements in the catalysts were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (ESCALAB 250 Xi system) equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6 eV) X-ray source. The sample charging effects were compensated by referring all binding energies (BE) to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. This reference gave BE values with an error within ± 0.1 eV. Here, the elemental compositions of the catalyst were derived through a simple conversion formula according to the atomic ratios given by XPS without applying any standardization procedure. To obtain the chemisorbed oxygen (Oads) ratio to the lattice oxygen (Olatt), we deconvoluted the obtained XPS spectra employing the XPSPEAK41 software after deducting the background signals using the Shirley algorithm. 2.4 Catalytic measurement The catalysts were evaluated using a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor. The corresponding schematic diagram of the apparatus is displayed in Fig. S1. In a typical test, 10.0 g Si powder was mixed homogeneously with 0.1 g of the prepared catalyst to form a “contact mass”, which was loaded into the reactor. The reactor system was initially purged with purified N2 (30 mL·min−1) at room temperature for 0.5 h and subsequently switched to the high-purity HCl gas flow. An anti-corrosion glass rotor flowmeter (LZB-3WB, 10–100 mL· min−1, Beijing Zhenanyu Flowmeter Instrument Co., Ltd, China) was used to control the HCl flow rate of 25 mL·min−1, and the reaction pressure was 0.1 MPa throughout this study. The reaction temperature was set in the range of 250–350 °C. After a given time, the reaction was stopped. The gas product was cooled into a liquid phase with a circulator bath controlled at − 5 °C by a programmable thermal circulator (GDH series, Ningbo Xinzhi biological technology Co., LTD). Gas chromatography (Agilent Technologies GC-7890A, thermal conducting detector (TCD)) was used to quantitatively analyze the products, mainly STC and TCS. Here, the by-products (e. g. Specifically, 0.5 g of the prepared catalyst with or without 0.5 g of Si powder (20–50 mesh) was thoroughly ground in an agate mortar for 8 min and then loaded into the reactor. The reactor system was purged with N2 for 0.5 h and then heated to the desired temperature for 1 h under N2 gas flow (25 mL· min−1). Subsequently, N2 was turned off, and HCl gas at a flow rate of 25 mL min−1 was introduced into the reactor at the desired temperature. After HCl chemisorption of the catalyst at different temperatures (25 °C, 200 °C, and 300 °C) for 6 h or different periods (0.5 h, 1 h, 1.5 h, 2 h, 4 h, and 6 h) at 300 °C, the catalysts were taken out and analyzed by XRD immediately. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 SEM and TEM observations Fig. S2 shows the morphologies of the synthesized CuO and Fe2O3-CuO catalysts. Pure CuO exhibits a flower-like morphology with an average diameter of 3 µm (Fig. S2a). The magnified image in Fig. S2b further reveals that the flower-like CuO comprises small Cu nanoparticles with a 100–400 nm size range. Compared with pure CuO, the Fe2O3-CuO catalyst maintains a similar morphology (Fig. S2c). However, as shown in Fig. S2d, there is an obvious change in the building block morphology of the flower-like Fe2O3-CuO catalyst. Many non-uniform nanorods or nanoflakes co-exist with aggregated nanoparticles in Fe2O3-CuO, suggesting that adding Fe species into CuO affected the formation of the flower-like structure during the preparation. As shown in Fig. S2d2-2d4, Cu (red), Fe (yellow), and O (blue) elements are almost homogeneously distributed throughout the whole particles. Additionally, the mass percentages of Cu, Fe, and O elements in Fe2O3-CuO quantified by EDS are determined to be 76.24%, 1.83%, and 21.92%, respectively (Fig. S2e). The Cu/Fe atomic ratio is close to the initial molar ratio of the precursors. These results indicate that the one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method successfully introduced Fe species into CuO. Fig. 2 shows the TEM images of the CuO and Fe2O3-CuO catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2a, aggregated nanoparticles and apparent inter-grain pores exist in the CuO catalyst. The Fe2O3-CuO catalyst shows similar grain-like structures of CuO (Fig. 2b). Figs. 2c and 2d show the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of CuO and Fe2O3-CuO, respectively. Due to the similarity of lattice spacing, the lattice spacing of 0.23 nm is tentatively assigned to the (111) plane of CuO [14,15]. Another lattice spacing of around 0.25 nm in Fe2O3-CuO is tentatively indexed to the (110) plane for Fe2O3 [16,17], which indicates that Fe species introduced by the hydrothermal method exist in the form of Fe2O3. 3.1.2 XRD analysis Fig. 3a shows the XRD patterns of all the samples. CuO, Fe2O3-CuO, and Fe2O3-CuO-M have similar diffraction patterns. The diffraction peaks at around 32.5°, 35.5°, 38.7°, 48.7°, 53.4°, 58.4°, 61.5°, 66.2°, 68.1°, 72.4° and 75.1° are indexed to the characteristic peaks of monoclinic CuO (JCPDS No. 48-1548), corresponding to the (110), (−111), (111), (−202), (020), (202), (−113), (−311), (220), (311), and (−222) planes, respectively [18]. In the pattern of FeO x , the diffraction peaks located at 2θ values of 24.1°, 33.2°, 35.6°, 40.9°, 49.5°, 54.1°, 62.4° and 64.0° can be assigned to the (012), (104), (110), (113), (024), (116), (214), and (300) planes of hematite Fe2O3 (JCPDS No. 33-0664), respectively [19]. The diffraction peak of Fe2O3 at 33.2° can be clearly observed in Fe2O3-CuO-M in Fig. 3b. However, this peak is not detected in Fe2O3-CuO, suggesting Fe2O3 has dispersed in the CuO phase. Additionally, compared with CuO and Fe2O3-CuO-M, there is a noticeable peak shift towards higher 2θ in the diffraction pattern of Fe2O3-CuO, indicating the shrinkage of the CuO lattice after introducing Fe2O3 by the one-pot hydrothermal method. The similar ionic radius of Cu2+ ions (0.73 Å) and Fe3+ (0.64 Å) can lead to partial substitution of Cu2+ by Fe3+ in Fe2O3-CuO [20]. The unit cell parameters and volume are further calculated from the XRD patterns and summarized in Table 1. The shrinkage in the crystal cell of CuO for Fe2O3-CuO implies the occupation of some Cu2+ sites by Fe3+. The average crystallite sizes of CuO in pure CuO and Fe2O3-CuO were further estimated using the Scherrer formula. As listed in Table 1, the average crystallite size of CuO in Fe2O3-CuO (31.1 nm) is slightly larger than that in CuO (29.0 nm). The two catalysts have identical median diameters (4.7 nm). Additionally, the specific surface area of CuO is 15.7 m2 g−1, larger than that of Fe2O3-CuO (9.1 m2·g−1). 3.1.3 H2-TPR analysis Fig. 4 shows the H2-TPR profiles of all the samples, and only one reduction peak in the temperature range of 250–550 °C is observed. For pure CuO, the reduction peak at 422 °C involves a two-step reduction of CuO, specifically, Cu2+ to Cu+ and Cu+ to metallic Cu0 [21,22]. The reduction peak at 486 °C for pure Fe2O3 is assigned to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 [23,24]. Compared with the pure CuO catalyst, the corresponding reduction peaks of Fe2O3-CuO and Fe2O3-CuO-M shift to lower temperatures, revealing that Fe2O3 promotes the reduction of CuO. 3.1.4 XPS analysis The valance states of the catalysts were analyzed by XPS, and the spectra are displayed in Fig. 5. As shown in the survey spectra in Fig. 5a, Cu, Fe, O, and C peaks are detected in Fe2O3-CuO. All binding energies were corrected by referencing the C 1s peak to 284.8 eV. Fig. 5b shows the Cu 2p XPS spectra of the two catalysts. The peaks located in the binding energy range of 934.7–935.2 eV and 954.8–955.3 eV can be assigned to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of CuO, respectively [25]. The corresponding satellite peaks at ca. 943.2–943.7 eV and 963.2–963.7 eV can also be observed. Compared with the pure CuO sample, the binding energy of the Cu element shifts toward a higher value for Fe2O3-CuO, suggesting the electron transfer from Cu to Fe [26,27]. The Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 5c) displays the main peaks of Fe 2p3/2 at 711.6 eV and Fe 2p1/2 at 725.2 eV, together with a satellite peak, indicating that Fe is at the +3 valence state in Fe2O3-CuO [28]. Fig. 5d shows the O 1s XPS spectra of the two catalysts, which can be deconvoluted to two kinds of oxygen species. The first peak at 531.4 eV is assigned to the chemisorbed oxygen (Oads), while the second peak at 529.8 eV is ascribed to the lattice oxygen (Olatt) [29,30]. The surface composition of the catalysts is listed in Table 2. The Oads/Olatt ratio of Fe2O3-CuO (1.4) is significantly larger than that of CuO (0.7), indicating that introducing Fe2O3 could increase the amount of the adsorbed oxygen species. Additionally, the surface content of Fe (23.0 wt%) is higher than the total Fe content (1.9 wt%) obtained by ICP, suggesting that Fe species tend to enrich on the surface of CuO. 3.2 Catalytic performance of catalysts The catalysts were tested for the silicon hydrochlorination reaction using metallurgical Si powder reacted with gas HCl at 300 °C for 6 h in a fixed bed. Table 3 lists the TCS selectivity (%), STC selectivity (%), and Si conversion (%) of the cases with the catalysts and without the catalyst. For the non-catalytic case, the TCS selectivity, STC selectivity, and Si conversion are 86.5%, 13.5%, and 15%, respectively. Using CuO as a catalyst, TCS selectivity increases to 98.4 %, and Si conversion reaches 21.6%, suggesting that CuO can promote the synthesis of TCS in the hydrochlorination of Si. The TCS selectivity and Si conversion are significantly improved by adding Fe2O3 into CuO. Although the TCS selectivities of Fe2O3-CuO and Fe2O3-CuO-M are similar (∼98%), Fe2O3-CuO has a higher Si conversion (59.4%) than Fe2O3-CuO-M (39.1%), which may originate from the stronger electron interaction between CuO and Fe2O3 in the former. In the later HCl chemisorption experiment, the key CuCl intermediate phase was detected, and the activity of the analytical pure CuCl as a reference sample was also evaluated. From Table 3, CuCl has a higher Si conversion than CuO, but lower than Fe2O3-CuO, suggesting that introducing Fe2O3 facilitates the formation of active phase. Additionally, it should be noted that pure Fe2O3 shows higher TCS selectivity but lower Si conversion than the non-catalytic case, suggesting that CuO is the main active site for the hydrochlorination of Si, while Fe2O3 behaves as an effective promoter. The effect of reaction temperature on the TCS selectivity and Si conversion was systematically investigated. As shown in Fig. 6a1, the reaction can only occur above 300 °C without a catalyst. After using the CuO or Fe2O3-CuO catalyst, the reaction can be initiated at 280 °C. The selectivities of TCS on the two catalysts are almost identical in the temperature range of 250–350 °C. However, Fe2O3-CuO has the highest Si conversion and TCS yield among all the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 6a2 and Fig. 6a3. Additionally, Si conversion increases with rising temperature in all cases. The reaction starts at 300 °C on Fe2O3-CuO-M, similar to the non-catalytic case. Moreover, the Si conversion on Fe2O3-CuO-M is lower than that on pure CuO at above 320 °C. Comparing the cases of Fe2O3-CuO and Fe2O3-CuO-M shows that the introduction of the promoter has a great influence on its catalytic performance. The influence of reaction time on the silicon hydrochlorination reaction was also investigated at 300 °C, as shown in Fig. 6b1, b2, and b3. As observed, the induction period (initial slow stage) of the silicon hydrochlorination reaction on catalysts follows the order: Fe2O3-CuO (1 h) < Fe2O3-CuO-M (2 h) < CuO (4 h) = no catalyst (4 h), suggesting that Fe2O3 as a promoter can significantly enhance the catalytic activity of CuO. As shown in Fig. 6 b1, in the presence of catalysts, the TCS selectivities reach above 97%, much higher than that in the non-catalytic case. From Fig. 6 b2, the Si conversion gradually increases with the prolongation of the reaction time. Among all these cases, Fe2O3-CuO exhibits the highest Si conversion. The TCS yield also shows a similar trend (Fig. 6 b3). To further confirm the promoting effect of the Fe2O3 promoter, the reaction rates (r) of the Si hydrochlorination reaction over the catalysts were measured, which follow the order of Fe2O3-CuO (35.4 mol/(gcat·h)) > Fe2O3-CuO-M (23.3 mol/(gcat·h)) > CuO (12.9 mol/(gcat·h)) > No catalyst (8.9 mol/(gcat·h)). Evidently, the introduction of Fe2O3 into CuO significantly increases the reaction rate. These results indicate that Fe2O3 is a good promoter for the hydrochlorination of Si. 3.3 Characterizations of the waste contact masses Fig. 7a displays the XRD patterns of the contact masses after a 6 h reaction. All the waste contact masses exhibit the characteristic peaks of Si and Cu but without CuO. The latter was consumed due to the reaction between HCl and the lattice oxygen from CuO. An enlargement of the XRD patterns in the range of 42°− 50° (Fig. 7b) shows the appearance of Cu x Si species in the two waste contact masses. Obviously, the peak intensity of Cu x Si in Fe2O3-CuO is stronger than that in CuO, suggesting that Fe2O3-CuO is more active in generating Cu x Si than the pure CuO catalyst. According to previous reports [9–12], the Cu x Si species are the key active intermediates for the hydrochlorination of Si, and the catalytic performances are closely related to the amount of Cu x Si. In this work, more Cu x Si species in Fe2O3-CuO lead to its higher catalytic activity. Fig. S3 shows the SEM images of the Si particles after the reaction using Fe2O3-CuO as the catalyst. The Si surface is coarse and porous after the reaction (Fig. S3a), suggesting that the etching occurred during the reaction process. Element mapping images (Fig. S3b and Fig. S3b1-b5 ) show the Si, Cu, O, Fe, and Cl distributions on the Si surface of the waste contact mass. The mapping image of Si (Fig. S3b1 ) clearly shows unreacted (bright purple) and reacted (dark purple) areas on the surface of Si particles. In the reacted areas, the Cu and Fe are distributed uniformly on the particle interface, indicating that a catalytic reaction occurs between Si particles and Cu-based catalysts. Additionally, the Cl element was also detected at the reacted surfaces of Si, which arises from the decomposition of HCl. 3.4 The structural evolution of the catalyst during HCl chemisorption process Fig. 8 shows the phase transformation of CuO and Fe2O3-CuO under HCl gas in the presence of Si powder. The measured XRD patterns in Fig. 8a indicate that the diffraction peaks of the mass contact are mainly assigned to Si and CuO. As shown in the enlarged XRD patterns in Fig. 8a1-a5, some new peaks attributed to CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O appear after being exposed to HCl for 1 h. When the exposure time is extended to 4 h, the diffraction patterns have no obvious change except the peak intensity of CuO (Fig. 8a1). However, at 6 h, the diffraction intensity of the peak at 28° is significantly enhanced, possibly due to the formation of the CuCl species. Simultaneously, the diffraction peaks corresponding to CuO at 35.5°, CuCl2 at 15.3°, and CuCl2·2H2O at 16.2° disappear (Fig. 8a2), while those of Cu x Si at 46.1°-46.3° and Cu at 43.3° are observed. The enlarged XRD patterns in the 2θ range of 46–46.4° are also presented to verify further the formation of Cu x Si at 6 h (Fig. 8a5). It is noted that after being exposed to HCl for different times, the catalyst was tightly sealed to reduce contact with air. Although it was still inevitable to contact with air before conducting XRD characterization, and the hydrolysis of the chloride residues might occur, no other Cu oxide species is seen in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8. Fe2O3-CuO underwent similar but faster phase transformations than CuO, as shown in Fig. 8b and the enlarged XRD patterns (Fig. 8b1-b4). In detail, the phase change of CuO in Fe2O3-CuO occurred at ca. in 4 h while that of single CuO was observed at 6 h, further suggesting that introducing Fe2O3 into CuO accelerated the phase transformation of CuO. Moreover, it should be noted that the CuCl phase only existed in the catalysts mixed with Si powder. In addition, the appearance of CuCl at 33.1° is accompanied by the formation of Cu x Si, indicating that CuCl may be the key intermediate for the diffusion between Cu and Si. As for the formation of the final Cu phase in the waste contact masses, there may be two reasons: (1) CuCl could break down into Cl- and Cu+. Some Cu+ that cannot immediately diffuse into the Si matrix may be reduced into Cu; (2) During the reaction between Cu x Si and HCl, the Cu phase will be formed if there is no available Si to ﬁll the consumed Si in Cu x Si. Table 4 lists the phase composition of the catalyst with Si powder after exposure to HCl at 300 °C for different reaction times. Compared with pure CuO, the exposure time required for forming the active Cu x Si phase is shorter for Fe2O3-CuO, suggesting that adding Fe2O3 promotes the formation of the active Cu x Si phase. Fig. S4 shows the XRD patterns of the CuO and Fe2O3-CuO catalysts without Si powder exposed to HCl at 300 °C for different times. Generally, CuO transforms to CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O after being exposed to HCl for some time. As shown in Fig. S4a and the enlarged view in Fig. S4a 1, the intensity of the peak at 35.5° attributed to the CuO phase gradually weakens with the extension of the exposure time. The intensity of the CuO peak in Fe2O3-CuO is very weak, from 0.5 h to 6 h (Fig. S4b and Fig. S4b1 ). From the enlarged view in Fig. S4a2 and Fig. S4b2 , the peak intensities of CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O vary at different exposure times to HCl. The variation is mainly due to two reasons: (1) CuCl2 could easily transform into CuCl2·2H2O by absorbing H2O in the air during the sample collection process after the HCl adsorption [31]. (2) There was a dynamic equilibrium between CuCl2·2H2O and CuCl2. In detail, the reaction between CuO and HCl can generate H2O, which is beneficial for forming CuCl2·2H2O. However, CuCl2·2H2O can be decomposed to CuCl2 at 300 °C. Fig. S5 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts exposed to HCl at different temperatures for 6 h. For the CuO catalyst (Fig. S5a, a1, and a2 ), the characteristic peaks of CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O appear after exposure to HCl for 6 h at room temperature (Fig. S5a), suggesting that HCl can efficiently react with CuO. From the enlarged XRD patterns (Fig. S5a1 ) measured at 300 °C, the peak intensity at 35.5° corresponding to CuO becomes very weak, implying that CuO may be nearly consumed. From Fig. S5a2 , as the temperature increases from 200° to 300°C, the intensity of the peak at 16.2° attributed to the CuCl2·2H2O phase decreases slightly, while the peak at 15.3° attributed to CuCl2 tends to increase. In contrast, the peak at 35.5° attributed to the CuO phase almost disappears, suggesting that CuO in Fe2O3-CuO completely transformed to CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O after 6 h of exposure to HCl at 200 °C (Fig. S5b and Fig. S5b1 ). A comparison of Fig. S5a and S5b suggests that introducing Fe2O3 promoted the phase transition of CuO. Moreover, different from pure CuO, the diffraction peak of CuO in Fe2O3-CuO reappears at 300 °C (Fig. S5b1 ), which may be caused by the thermal decomposition of Cu(OH)2 produced by hydrolysis of CuCl2 [31]. In addition, similar to CuO, the intensity of the peak at 16.2° attributed to the CuCl2·2H2O phase drops while that attributed to the CuCl2 phase increases with rising temperature (Fig. S5b2 ), which may be because CuO is more easily converted to anhydrous CuCl2 at high temperatures. From the above analysis, it is speculated that the phase transformation of the catalyst under HCl may follow the following steps: (I) CuO+2HCl→CuCl2+H2O (II) CuCl2+2H2O→CuCl2·2H2O (III) CuCl 2 · 2 H 2 O → ∆ CuCl 2 + 2 H 2 O First, HCl is adsorbed on the catalyst surface and then directly reacts with CuO, forming H2O and CuCl2 (reaction I). The formed CuCl2 further partially transforms to CuCl2·2H2O when encountering water (reaction II). With the increase of the reaction temperature and time, CuCl2·2H2O can further decompose into CuCl2 (reaction III). Additionally, CuCl2 may also undergo hydrolysis to produce Cu(OH)2 (although not detected) in the presence of water [31] during the HCl chemisorption process and further completely decompose to produce CuO. Evidenced by the H2-TPR and XPS characterizations, the introduction of Fe2O3 facilitates lattice oxygen migration due to the interaction between Fe2O3 and CuO, thus accelerating the phase transformation of CuO in Fe2O3-CuO. 3.5 Catalytic mechanism The mechanism of the Fe2O3-CuO-catalyzed hydrochlorination of Si can be illustrated in Fig. 9 by combining the above results and previous studies [9–12]. When HCl is introduced into the contact mass, the HCl molecules first adsorb on the catalyst surface and are further dissociated (Fig. 9a). The CuO phase changes to CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O (Fig. 9b), then to CuCl and Cu (Fig. 9c). With a rising temperature and extended time, CuCl becomes more active and then spreads to the surface of the Si matrix to attack the Si-Si bonds. Afterward, the active phase Cu x Si composed of electropositive Cu+ and electronegative Si- is formed (Fig. 9d). Subsequently, Cu+ adsorbs Cl- while Si- adsorbs H+. Eventually, the electronegative Cl- diffuses to the Si surface and combines with Si to form the TCS product. Once the Si in Cu x Si is consumed, the bulk Si migrates into the Cu x Si matrix to ﬁll the vacancy and regenerate the active Cu x Si phase. Because of the continuous consumption and migration of Si, the etching region develops on the Si surface (Fig. 9e). As discussed in Section 3.4, introducing Fe2O3 into CuO can accelerate these processes, making it easier for the formation of active Cu x Si species, thereby facilitating the reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Fe2O3-CuO catalyst synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method is tested for Si hydrochlorination to produce TCS. It performs better than the pure CuO and mechanically mixed Fe2O3-CuO-M catalysts. The strong electron interactions between Fe and Cu species promote the oxygen migration in Fe2O3-CuO. The HCl chemisorption result shows that CuO undergoes a series of phase transformations under HCl from CuO to CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O, then to CuCl and Cu. Tracking the reaction process by XRD suggests that the CuCl intermediate phase is the key to generating the active Cu x Si sites. Introducing Fe2O3 accelerates the phase transformation of CuO with Si powder and the formation of active Cu x Si sites in Fe2O3-CuO, thus leading to its higher catalytic performance. The ﬁndings in this work provide new insights into the catalytic hydrochlorination of Si to produce TCS using Cu-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic hydrochlorination of Si is an effective route to manufacture trichlorosilane (TCS), the main feedstock of high-purity Si for solar cells. However, the understanding of its catalytic process is still limited. Herein, we prepared CuO catalysts modified with Fe2O3 promoter (Fe2O3-CuO) by one-step hydrothermal method and investigated their catalytic performance for producing TCS. Compared with the non-catalytic case, pure CuO catalyst, and the Fe2O3-CuO-M catalyst obtained by mechanically mixing CuO with Fe2O3, the Fe2O3-CuO catalyst exhibits the highest TCS selectivity and Si conversion. The introduction of Fe2O3 facilitates lattice oxygen migration of CuO due to the electron interactions between Fe2O3 and CuO. During the reaction, CuO transforms into CuCl2 and CuCl2·2H2O, then to CuCl. The latter is the key intermediate for forming the active Cu x Si phase. This work discloses the transformation of the CuO catalyst during the Si hydrochlorination reaction, and provides new insights into the catalytic mechanism.
